Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant: Fuel Use in Traditional Societies

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Dr. Alexia Smith and Lucas Proctor, of the University of Connecticut, will use archaeobotany to study how periods of social and political change affect peoples' energy use and fuel consumption. The collection and burning of wood, plant, or dung-based fuels is an essential daily task in the lives of people living in non-industrial societies, on par with the acquisition of food and shelter. Archaeologists have often noted that deforestation quickly follows the emergence of socio-economically complex societies and early states as a result of increased fuel needs. As populations grew and economic activities intensified, maintaining an adequate supply of fuel resources would have been increasingly important. This study examines how fuel economies change in response to a shift towards increasing socioeconomic and political complexity. While the developed world no longer relies on wood or dung fuels, many areas of the developing world still depend on access to forests and pasturelands to supply their daily energy needs. By exploring how people in early complex societies coped with fuel needs and fuel scarcity, this research will contribute to national and global discussions about the role of energy resources in sustainable economic development. An understanding of how socioeconomic factors affect how people collect and use fuel resources over long periods of time is essential to the development of forest conservation and environmental policies that can balance energy needs with the preservation of natural resources.

The researchers use archaeobotany, the study of how plants and people interact, and geoarchaeological techniques, to identify and interpret fuel remains from three archaeological sites located in Northern Mesopotamia that date to the Late Chalcolithic (ca. 5300-3100 BC) and Assyrian (1300-611 BC) periods. The Late Chalcolithic in this region saw the emergence of the first socio-economically complex villages and cites, while the Assyrian period witnessed the development of the expansive Assyrian Empire, which fundamentally transformed land use patterns across the region and local administrative control of resources. Combining multiple lines of evidence from carbonized seed and wood remains, microscopic calcitic ash residues, and ethnoarchaeological data, will provide a rigorous evaluation of what fuel types were used at each site, whether different fuels or different wood species were preferred for certain tasks or by people of different statuses, and how fuel affected land use practices. The results of this project will contribute to three larger collaborative research projects that bring together international researchers and local archaeologists from Iraqi Kurdistan, Syria, and Turkey in order to study the early development of social complexity in an area of endangered cultural heritage.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The collection and burning of biomass fuel resources for cooking, heating, and pyrotechnology were essential tasks in the daily lives of people prior to the widespread adoption of fossil fuels. In ancient Mesopotamia, where the first urban, hierarchically organized polities emerged 6000 years ago, fuel needs would have needed to change in response to increasing populations, urbanism, deforestation, developments in pyrotechnology and economic development.

In this study, we examined fuel remains from three archaeological sites located in northern Mesopotamia, Surezha, Tell Zeidan, and Ziyaret Tepe, to better understand how early communities provisioned themselves with fuel resources. At the pre-urban sites of Surezha and Tell Zeidan, we found evidence for the use of a variety of fuel resources, including several species of firewood, animal dung cakes, and cereal grain processing waste. The widespread use of non-woody fuels at both sites was an important discovery. While such fuels often considered to be “alternative” fuels, used only when wood resources are scarce due to aridity or deforestation, our analysis identified their use alongside wood resources in the Chalcolithic Age, long before widespread deforestation in the region is thought to have occurred and just prior to the emergence of the first cities. Furthermore, at Tell Zeidan it was possible to identify the selection of different fuels between household hearths and industrial pyrotechnic features—hinting at emerging technological specialization in fuel selection during a period when important innovations in pyrotechnology leading up to metallurgy were being developed. At the third site, Ziyaret Tepe, fuel remains documented changing patterns of fuel exploitation and land use related to the site’s development into an important urban settlement within the Neo-Assyrian Empire. During this period, fuel data provides evidence for the overexploitation and depletion of local woodlands. This corresponds well with existing textual accounts from the area describing widespread deforestation and the need for dangerous expeditions into neighboring kingdoms to acquire timber for costly building projects in the imperial heartland of Assyria.

In addition to gaining insight into human-environment relationships during important periods of increasing sociopolitical complexity, this study has the potential inform broader efforts to promote sustainable fuel burning practices and vegetation conservation within developing countries. People in the past used a wide breadth of fuel sources as a risk reduction strategy against overexploitation, as well as to efficiently recycle agropastoral byproducts like dung and cereal chaff, as was demonstrated at the sites of Surezha and Tell Zeidan Failure to manage fuel resources, as was the case at Assyrian Ziyaret Tepe, can lead to overexploitation of natural resources and deforestation/environmental degradation.
